text: Hi, this is Kate from MinuteEarth.

The biggest waves on Earth - those that are
the height of entire office buildings - become

truly gigantic because of what happens out
of sight.

That’s because waves don’t just sit on
the surface; the waves’ energy can extend
more than 1500 meters below it.

Once a wave reaches shallow enough water,
it makes contact with the seafloor.

In most places around the world, the seafloor
gently slopes upward, slowly pushing the wave’s

energy above the surface, while friction against
the seafloor slows it down.

This creates an unstable column of water and
energy that eventually comes crashing down;
that’s a “break.”

But the seafloor doesn't always slope gently,
and its shape is what makes or breaks a break.

Big underwater geological features like reefs
can get in a wave's way and compress its energy.

All that energy gets abruptly funneled up
into a shallow channel - something like a

four-lane highway’s worth of traffic being
forced to suddenly merge into one lane.

But while cars can use their brakes to slow
down and dissipate their excess energy, waves

can’t, and the resulting pile-up bursts
over the barrier in huge, dramatic wave breaks.

But the biggest waves on earth occur in places
where undersea canyons not only funnel massive

amounts of wave energy into a narrow channel,
but also launch that energy over a shelf just
before the shoreline.

For example, during the most recent ice age,
a combination of rivers and tectonic activity

carved the V-shaped Nazaré Canyon into the
continental shelf off Portugal's coast.
And then oceans rose and filled it back in.

As a wave moves through the 230-kilometer-long,
ever-narrowing canyon, its energy gets funneled

into a more focused - and therefore stronger
- wave.

But since the canyon remains several thousand
meters deep, the wave energy inside it doesn’t

touch the seafloor, and it doesn’t get slowed
down...yet.

Meanwhile, wave energy moving alongside the
canyon’s edges gets bent inside it too - like

multiple onramps adding cars to a highway
- further boosting the wave’s energy.

At the canyon’s narrowest point, right before
the shore, the seafloor shoots up at a nearly

vertical angle, creating a natural seawall
that compresses all that energy - essentially
blocking 7 lanes of an 8-lane highway.

That energy then gets launched up; the resulting
ten-story-tall breaks are truly the biggest
waves you will ever "sea."
